title: What is the extent of susceptibility to hypnosis and magnetism in individuals beyond those with hysteria?
first_phrase: This last 200 token text discusses the opinions of various doctors and researchers on the use of hypnotism and magnetism, particularly in relation to hysteria and the potential to induce sleepwalking. The author argues that the belief that only hysterics can be hypnotized is a misconception and that people of all ages and backgrounds can be influenced by magnetic forces. They note that certain doctors disagree with this view and insist on studying only hysteric patients. The text concludes that the field of magnetism has many unexplored possibilities and that it can even be used for improving an individual's moral and intellectual character through somnambulistic suggestion.

last_phrase: In conclusion, the history and practices of magnetic and hypnotic phenomena are complex and multifaceted, with many differing interpretations and approaches by experts in the field. While there is still much debate on the validity of certain phenomena, it is clear that these practices have had a significant impact on the development of fields such as electrotherapy and psychotherapy. It is important to approach the study of these phenomena with patience, prudence, and careful consideration, and to acknowledge the contributions of those who have come before in the pursuit of understanding the mysteries of the human mind.
